review_title: Really depends on department you get into
pros: Exposure to all HQ processes, access to resources and decision-makers otherwise hardly reachable from overseas departments, secure employment (if you're on a permanent contract), good payment (if negotiated properly beforehand) and good profit-sharing system (if you happen to be included in one). Marketing jobs in IMC in telecom, for instance, are totally different from engineering ones -- much more freedom and access to some stuff going on in HQ. So it really depends where you'd land.
cons: Growth is limited and slow, isolation if you don't speak Korean (both interpersonally and professionally), bureaucracy, long and ineffective hours (though foreigners are generally more flexible on that), lack of decision-making power and negative feedback on non-conformism with upper management.

review_title: Worked for Samsung Electronics - TV, Excellent experience, many sacrifices
pros:
You get high experience in your field. Even professionals with previous experience. A good position with market exposure and responsibility, will allow you to develop further and see results. 
you just adopt and learn from different culture in a global - innovative organization. If you get the trust of your Business Unit - Leader, then you can do even more things, with direct market impact. 
Great to work with people from all around the world 
Fluid and quick changing environment, dictated by the continuous changes in  markets
Opportunity for high achievements and proud to see your work results.
All the above allow you to build stamina and develop yourself for future challenges in other positions - organizations
cons:
100% corporation life. 
No work - life balance AT ALL. 
Management is very hard, strict, crazy sometimes...beyond any imagination. Sort of military structure and discipline. 
You are just a number. Accept it or don't apply to work for this company
Recommended only if you are willing to 100% accept ALL of the above

review_title: Good programming experience and well known company
pros:
- Fast paced environment. If you want to grow as a programmer, this company is one of the best starting ground for you!
- Algorithm and certifications exam. Opportunity to learn here is one of the best since they provide good Continuous Learning Programs (CLP) and trainings internally. 
- Easy opportunity for business trip in Korea or in the US
- Excellent minded people. People are well versed in their own jobs as well as their algorithmic capabilities.
- Good management. Managers at the moment are considerate and will make you feel comfortable.
- Discount!
cons:
- High company politics. Don't expect to elevate into the higher ups that easily.
- low increase in salary per annum
- Micromanaging. At the end of the day, work above all else.

review_title: Great people but poor management from HQ
pros: Very many talented people at this office
cons:
HQ has too many back and forth non-essential requirement changes that end up in countless/pointless efforts.
The fast expansion has left Samsung HQ with too many junior people managing projects/products/tasks that they don't really have qualified experiences/knowledge for.
HQ is not giving this particular office enough room/freedom to really drive a product (lack of trust or fear of loss of control seem to be the key issue here)

pros:
Big company with big reputation and you work on the cool devices and features. Free food with competitive salary in korea. Big campus, young engineers and get discount on samsung products.
House or housing fee is provided for foreign employees.  And most of the systems are translated to english, so korean is not required. But will be better if you know some korean. Will have some free time for self development . A good career ladder. Trying to change company to global leader, and tries to become as hospitable as possible for foreigners
cons:
Top to bottom approach.  They dont listen foreign engineers usually and neglected. Most of the works are just bug fixing or unnecessary things. Not many challenging stuff.  
Not many things to learn unless you develop yourself. Seminars and development lectures are all in korean. 
Most of the managers work to please their bosses, and just to show off.

review_title: A fantastic company to start your career at
pros:
The size and scale of  Samsung might give outsiders the expectation that those in entry-level positions are a very small cog in a far larger machine. In my experience this was anything but the case. 

SEUK gives those who want to take on new opportunities and challenges, every chance to do so. I joined as a graduate, and in that time worked on projects and accounts that I never expected I'd be able to. 

Hard work is very much rewarded, and while the extrinsic, financial rewards and incentives are a big plus, its the intrinsic satisfaction from the role that Samsung provides. However, I have no doubt that this varies from department to department, but based on my time there, I'd recommend Samsung to anyone.
cons:
Top-down leadership is very much a factor, but I'd wager this is the same with most multi-national brands.

Internal processes and systems can be slow and arduous at times, with work sometimes being held up by approvals and software issues.

job_title: Samsung Experience Consultant in New York, NY
pros: Good pay, Co workers will feel like a family. But ofcourse that can be due to the same stress and abuse we are all receiving.
cons: Management consistently will threaten your job to "motivate" you. Even though you are a hourly employee they will continue to give you work to do at home. Higher management is direct samsung employees all they focus is on sales and numbers when our actual job tittle doesn't say anything about it. Don't trust Mosaic HR they tell samsung everything, they much rather keep their contract with samsung then protect employees; so you are eventually targeted and just end up getting fired. They will make it impossible for you to request time off and will not pay your for sick days or personal days if you do not tell them every detail as to why you are sick. They pay is good but not worth the headache and stress. My warning to you don't do it.

review_title: Interesting tasks but not that good management
pros: Interesting tasks that can involve cutting-edge computer science (for me it was machine learning). It is possible to transfer between different projects and departments.
cons:
Korean management. You do not get negative feedback. It's not that rare that your emails when you are proactively asking about status of your project or it's drawbacks are simply ignored. Also, many projects have hard deadlines but too vague requirements which result in the lack of acceptance criteria. It is your team's responsibility to come up with something that would amuse management on several levels of hierarchy.

About paycheck. It's better to come to this place with PhD degree or 10+ years of experience. Otherwise your salary's growth would be almost non-existent.

review_title: Stay away from this place. Stay healthy.
pros: I don't want to consider punctual salaries as a pro. To work is your duty, to be paid is your right.
cons: If it really does exist the concept of circus in a company, you can find it at Cheil Industries. No job descriptions, no roles, only lies. Today you can be a manager and tomorrow you will be used as a warehouseman, independently from your background and expertise. Don't hope to make a career there inside, unless you are Korean. The biggest risk is to forget how to work, as there inside you just play something unintellegible. There is a huge difference of salary treatment among Korean people and other ethnicities' ones. They will try with all their efforts to keep some money from your settlement, when you leave, as they consider a shame the fact that you're leaving this company and they will get offended like children. It is strong their attempt to make you think as a Korean, as they don't want to accept that they're working in a foreign country. The management is composed by people that don't even know their name, nor why they've been put there.

pros:
Promptly reimbursed expenses without having to wait on client's to pay.
Well Organized company, and all goes well if done within the correct time frame such as travel etc.
cons:
Seems that special shopping discounts on company's website was kept secret between upper management. Lower end personnel seem to have no access. Seems like lots of politics at the top.

Upper management has access to information regarding equipment and always attend training class, but the field personnel doing the actual work doesn't get trained and has to figure out how to troubleshoot issues, until someone decides to do their job and walk us through.

review_title: Don't join unless you are willing to be bullied and have your morals compromised
pros:
- The company employ excellent talent, however do not then value the ideas and opinion of those individuals once it is within the organisation. 
- Samsung is a great name to have on your CV and will open a lot of doors to other organisations
cons:
- There are several incidents of racism, ageism and sexism that occur by the senior management team and there is nobody at a senior level that is willing to challenge those ideas and behaviours. Cultural differences aside, you can't operate in that way within a European environment and it very much compromises your morals and the way in which you are comfortable working.  
- The company will burn you out and then discard you. There is no loyalty to the "Westerners" they "buy in" to the organisation and the significant efforts they make to the organisation. 
- Within the European HQ, generally bullying is the management style of choice
- Long working hours are expected and are the norm, no appreciation of going over and above will occur and there will be no celebration of successes before having to move rapidly onto the next task.

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros: Health benefit is good.  Good bonus.  Mostly not busy.
cons: The culture is rotten from the root.  From HQ, the very heirarchical culture gives little respect and room of freedom to lower level engineers.  Being a remote office in San Jose, we did not get to experience the worst.  But the local management here is super impowered over those ruled engineers.  Power plays.  Opaque..  Favoritism.  Politics.  Zero trust top down.  It is very difficult to feel proud and willing to contribute when knowing that as an employee you are not really treated as part of the company.  The best way to get company or organizational update is via Internet or grapevine.  Several almost got their pays doubled over several years, while most hardly moved an inch.  A few are very happy, most however are exploited.  The company force installs spyware on employees computers.  employees are not the esset of the company.  There is some fundamental philosophical problems with the company and the local management.

pros: As an expat hire, Samsung pays well, the benefits are good, and in general the work-life balance is not bad (although this varies significantly between teams).  Can be a fascinating experience to see how the company operates.
cons: Samsung resembles much more a military organization than a corporate entity.  Communication flows top - down, anyone under VP or even SVP has little decision making authority, middle management is not paid to think but to execute orders, and promotions are based on a persons age and political connections, not necessarily competence.

review_title: Discriminatory Performance Evaluation Practice to Foreign Employees
pros: Tons of company resources, great benefits, amazing infrastructure
cons: This company lures foreign recruits to come work at their Korea HQ with competitive salaries.  Unfortunately, they do not tell you that there is a double standard for performance evaluations.   They never communicated this ahead of time. There was no transparency at all.  Foreigners are evaluated at a higher standard because of their higher incomes.  You want to hold foreigners at higher standard because of their higher pay? then give them a higher position that would be aligned with their salary so that they can deliver on higher expectations.  This is discriminatory.  Their bait and switch practice is very questionable and incredibly unfair

review_title: Exciting workplace bogged down by bureaucracy
job_title: Assistant Product Manager in Ridgefield, NJ
pros: Great coworkers, fantastic benefits (excellent insurance, with most of the premiums covered by the company, 401K match, excellent employee purchase program). cons: Too many proprietary systems and processes, I do not feel like my experience here helped contribute to my career prospects in more modern companies. You are constantly working within a Korean mindset, with ridiculous goals often established without any regard to actual market conditions, and can change at the drop of a hat when a new executive decides he wants to try something  different.

review_title: Decent employer for the experience of living abroad but dont expect a leading role or to be challenged.
pros: I guess the best reasons to be employed by  Samsung in Korea is to have the benefit of working with one of the largest electronic manufacturers in the world. The experience of being apart of such a fast paced design team and organizing your work ethic around a different business culture was unique.
cons: Long hours, a sense of duty and unwavering commitment to Samsung codes of conduct. Work to free time ratio was awful. Questionable management practices in regards to foreign employees. ( Not knowing how to properly lead and implement a growing environment)

pros: People there are very nice up front. There are a lot of coffee breaks.
cons: Way too bureaucratic. I spent two days of every week putting together a 30 page report and presentation of what I worked on for the other 3 days. Everyone's time is pretty much spent answering to higher ups. Typical corporate culture. There is no such thing as work life balance. If you don't stay there until 11 pm overnight, you are considered lazy. Oh, and don't even think about leaving before your boss. God forbid he'll notice and immediately scold you for being lazy.

pros: I thoroughly enjoy working at Samsung Research. The people make it for me. As a new employee I have found the leadership team are open, transparent and encouraging . Everyone I've met have been friendly and welcoming.  It's a mature culture whereby I've been given the trust and support to suggest new things and shape my own role. There is a great learning culture with constant opportunities to upskill and grow knowledge. It's very much a multi-cultural environment which creates opportunities to collaborate from many different perspectives. The social side is great, in the short time I've been here there have been several team lunches and I hear the Christmas & summer parties are epic! We have a heavily subsidised canteen onsite that offers both western and Korean food. The pay and benefits are also very competitive so all in all it has been a great career move for me.
cons: None that I can think of!

pros: International ambitions because of increasingly competitive domestic market has forced Korean EPC companies overseas.  Strong potential because of Samsung Group's brand name and balance sheet.  Open-minded to a variety of deal types and geographic locations.
cons: The company does not operate on meritocracy.  The tenure upon hire system for the Koreans and age-based advancement system drastically reduces employees' incentive to perform and instead propagates a lot of politics.   More importantly, this environment slows down the skill development of its employees.  There is widespread incompetence across multiple divisions, whether, technical, financial, legal, or corporate management.  For example, investment committee heads who don't understand basic finance concepts or technical directors who can't read drawings.  If one enters as a specialist in a certain field, Koreans will block every attempt to improve existing systems because of their fear of being exposed and general resentment about being paid less than foreigners.  Most foreign hires are reduced to figurehead positions with no decision making power.

pros: friendly working atmosphere and not too aggressive sales targets. good salary compared to rival companies and flexible due to the amount of locations.
cons: Some people might want the structured working environment where if you do activity A it results in B, where in sales the results can have many different outcomes such as a customer not buying, the competitor is outselling you, and the list goes on.

pros: pay is the only reason - I will leave as soon as I'm able
cons: American workers are merely puppets.  The Koreans run the whole show and the dual management structure (One Korean and one American manager) is enough to drive one crazy.  The direction is mainly from the immediate American manager but if a Korean manager says something you are expected to say "how high" when they say "jump."  There is no communication between groups and no accountability.  Promotions are for the most part given to "corp" engineers who are trained straight out of college in the "Samsung Way."  One group now managed by a "corp" engineer has an incredibly high turnover rate and yet he is still manager.  Diversity is getting better but promotions, hiring, etc. are still dominated by those of Korean origin.

review_title: Basically a boat sailing without a compass
pros:

With this, the company served as the brain of the entire conglomerate. However, after the Asian Financial Crisis in 1997, Lee Gun Hee decided to allow all Samsung companies to conduct import/export on their own. C&T lost its main role, and most of the essential employees left the firm, which exactly explains the company's decline since. Now the company is a commodity trader with less than 1% of net profit rate. I worked on complex Excel sheets to predict the company's profit for 2020 August and, believe it or not, without backing this up with ANY strategy. The company is 75 years old and has some serious mis-guided culture.

pros:
You are looked after materially. Good salary and benefits (new fully expensed BMW or Audi every 3yrs for example), generous staff discounts, generous expenses policy etc etc
Some amazingly talented individuals.
A good brand for the CV
cons:
- Your career will stagnate. Training and career progression paths are non-existent, and you are not allowed to make any real decisions, so it's not too long before you end up in a rut where you turn up, keep your head down, fudge the reports and take the cheque every month.

- Reporting is the end game in this company. Reality doesn't matter, it's how good the reports look to the next level of management up that counts for everything. And because such a vast quantity of data is reported so ridiculously frequently, it simply isn't humanly possible for any of what you report to ever be checked or verified. Combine this with the fact that you start every project knowing the strategy will change, or the goalposts move long before anything ever gets delivered, and the fact that your department head will ultimately be someone with no understanding of what it is that you actually do, and you can pretty much get away with doing nothing. Just keep the reports coming, and work late occasionally to "show commitment". I did this for several of my four years and got very good appraisals and bonuses every time because I played the political game. It's farcical, it really is.

- Promotions happen on length of service, how many hours a week you put in (turn up on Sundays and schmooze with the Koreans if you really want to look good) and whether your face fits, not your ability to do your job, or what your output is. 

No flexibility in terms of working from home or from other office locations, with a primary school style 'Bums on seats' mentality. Ultimately, Korean management has no trust or respect for Westerners. There isn't a single important decision made in this company that isn't ultimately signed off (and often reversed at the last minute) by a Korean. Even senior Westerners have to defer to Korean "superiors" who almost always are less experienced and knowledgeable than they are, but are in charge because they are Korean. The racism openly displayed in this company simply wouldn't be tolerated if Western and Korean roles were reversed, but as with most things, it's excused as "culture".

- When you leave and go to a company with a 21st century management style of empowerment and trust, you actually find yourself struggling a little bit with simple decisions and freedoms because not once at Samsung will you ever have had any real autonomy. And when you're deprived of it, and then it's reinstated, it can be a almost uncomfortable at first. And in a nutshell that is the biggest problem. It is very easy to leave here a less relevant, and less employable individual than you were when you joined...

pros: Product discounts, a few nice people

pros: Incredible technology.  Very ambitious company.  Will dominate for the foreseeable future.  Lot of opportunity internally to advance.  Treat employees and junior staff very well. cons: Focus on reporting back to HQ as a priority versus dealing with key customer/partner or other local market focus and priorities.  An over abundance of employees sent from HQ to regions to monitor staff performance.  Rotational management from HQ sent to run subsidiaries do not always possess appropriate skills or the time to adjust to the local scenario.

review_title: Korean Business Culture and issues--even in the USA offices
pros: Budgets are available if you have an appropriate cause. Excellent benefits, especially health coverage. Good support for travel.
cons:
Money/Profit obsessed company (but that makes them successful) Lots of politics, meetings, and endless reports & reports of reports. Korean business culture and hierarchy, even in the USA. After hours drinking expected. Demands of managers or their bosses trump any customer request. Expect to drop everything when upper management from Korea visits. If you are not Korean, you will not make much progress. Use this company as a stepping stone.
Management changes every year in December, so there is yearly turmoil and disorganization until the new boss settles in.

review_title: Good for some, bad for many
pros: Good focus on innovation, good training opportunities, many software contests etc to help you build your skills. Great free veg and non veg food, free AC buses. exciting tech areas to work on.
cons: Too much politics and regionalism, bad appraisal system where only the favorites get good ratings year after year while rest are screwed, lack of transparency from the management (saying its going well when they really intend to fire people). Salary hike much below average if you get an average rating. Long working hours, bad work life balance, min 9 hours every day, no work from home. Endless work hours if you are in Korea HQ. Managers are sub standard technically and with people skills.

pros:
- Samsung has the broad business portfolio, and it's like they have many baskets to put their eggs. This makes the stability of the whole group quite high.
- Very strong in component and manufacturing business.
- Has the solid system to manage the large organization.
- Trying hard to adapt to the fast changing trend.
- In South Korea, working culture is relatively reasonable.
cons:

- Korean local working culture; Work-life imbalance (though they're trying to change it)

pros: The people are the best reason by Far to work for Samsung.

Samsung is a Korean company - but the Koreans micromanage EVERY aspect of business-to the point it's counter-productive.  Everything has to have approval from Koreans prior to coming to fruition - and Koreans will ask a million questions about why you are requesting whatever it is you want.   Way too many hands in the pot.  Also-Koreans don't like anyone who is not Korean or at the very least Asian.  All upper-management is Korean.

review_title: Too many people trying to manage and control others rather than doing their actual work

review_title: Good experience and lots of things to learn if you can adopt korean culture.

Usually only one person makes all the decisions while others just follow up since you are not supposed to argue wit older people in korean culture.

review_title: Great experience if you stay less than a year

I have seen improvements but the hierarchy and internal red tape will lead to its demise.  Employees learn a lot quickly but the unspoken rule says get out within a year to avoid stagnation.  Hopefully Samsung will one day treat its employees like grown ups.

cons: The company doesn't trust on its employers - unless they are from HQ. So if you were hired in a management position in your country and expect to apply your knowledge to contribute with the business, just forget it. All strategies are made in HQ without sharing it with their international management. If you really care about working on something great, this is not the place for you.

review_title: As a field sales assistant, we're proposing purchase orders to the store managers. It's very challenging and exciting.
pros: Why? Because you will be a great sales man. From 0 to 100 real quick. Because they will train you and teach you to be a better sales coordinator and to improve your skills.
cons: Talking to the managers who we are dealing with. We need to get their mindset and discuss all the current promotions we are offering. Best deal for more quantity and big discounts.

pros:
- Samsung recruits lot of freshers from good institutions. So your peers are pretty competitive and they push your limits.
- Projects create great impact given Samsung has such a huge consumer base
cons:
- Teams do not have good synergy. Few teams often work on the same projects. Teams do not support other teams as they don't want others to get credit.
- Most freshers do not have proper mentors as the management is not technically strong. Senior people have been in the organisation for a long time and are trained more in the politics rather than the technical capabilities. Their first motive would be to keep their job safe than to keep the team moving

pros: Great place to get in touch with the latest technology and understand the structure of a super large multinational company. Compensations are above average for senior level staff and executives.
cons: No work & life balance. Korean-style management can sometimes be very demanding and rigid. Flexibility is not something you can enjoy here. People from the headquarters sometimes don't really have the first grasp of the local markets and could make decisions based on insufficient information which results in endless paperwork and reporting but no substantial improvement.

review_title: Great place to work with intelligent people in a fast-paced environment in a short term
pros: One of the few companies that spends and affords lots resource on improving employee's professional quality with its education program, regular-based workshop, etc. and provides profound opportunities for self-challenging and developing best practice in the industry
cons: Unsustainable & unpleasant place to work in terms of work-life balance and work environment. Also, it's harsh to its employee. Extremely top-down management style and with very limited respect to its stakeholders. KPI-driven and most humanity are left behind

pros: The company benefits like sponsoring business trips is one good thing. But all this also comes at the cost of lobbying and favoritism .
cons:
The higher management is just a puppet in the hands of the VPs (mostly Koreans). The people at entry level are generally brilliant since they lure top institute candidates with fancy looking packages. But sadly there's a huge crunch in the team leaders, and this devoid the freshers from any sort of mentor-ship. Since my tenure, almost forty per cent of the team has resigned but instead of filling in people at senior levels, the management brings in more and more freshers. Also the Korean work style doesnt go down well with a lot of people. Employees sit in the office doing nothing, just in order to complete the "mandatory" 9 hours shift. 
This is not a place for creative people.

pros: Good pay, Great Insurance policy and Brand Name. Learning happens on the job when you work for such a big player.
cons: Poor work life balance, illogical tactics, callous management who disregards the interests of distributors who are investing their money in the business, and treats off role team like dirt, burdening them with mindless data collection, also cascades negative energy down to all team members, incapable people are leading Regions and National Teams, leading to problems.

pros: In Korea, you get respect for working at Samsung due to the dominance that the company enjoys in country. The company is above the law and knows it very well. However, this can lead to some personal dilemmas for employees who have outward facing roles.
cons: Executives are hired based on relationships with current executives, instead of ability. When the executive's lack of ability finally shows, they are moved to do damage at other groups within the company. This is especially demoralizing when that exec is a foreigner and local Korean employees see said exec being chauffeured around Korea in a luxury car.

review_title: Don't work there if you're looking for a professional, responsible and fair organization
pros: The benefits; the pay, looks good on resume. The pay is good because they overload you with work.
cons:
1- Strategic decision making is all done by the Korea head office HQ; HQ makes impulsive decision making and orders the small local offices around to execute things. Local managers have no power or any role in the strategic decision making. 

2- No work life balance at all because of the work load; this will not work for you if you have a family. 

3- excessive and time-consuming reporting required to management. Inefficient daily work flow. Careless about process improvement. Impulsive decision making that lacks proper planning. 

4- big communication gap between the Korean management and other employees. Other-ethnic employees cannot grow professionally in this company because higher level positions are taken by Koreans from home country.

review_title: Okay.  Good experience & pay... but that is it
job_title: Senior Product Marketing Manager in Ridgefield Park, NJ
pros: household name, good retail/product marketing experience, pay, vacation days
cons: All business decisions come from mother ship in S. Korea.  Soul-less, no personality, no fun, sterile environment, sterile people, good old boys network, spend tons of time on things that do no really matter and dont move the needle, very executional and tactical vs using your brain and data to make strategic decisions.

pros: Great company as far as brand recognition,  innovation,  the current direction they are heading.  They have the best products in the market, and are continuing to produce high quality products.
cons: Very few opportunities to move upward in the retail sales field.  The saying "The winds of change are fast in Samsung" is 100% accurate.  Directives are constantly changing, sometimes disconnect between  upper management and the field teams.   Korean company, so very heavily based on Work hard... Work harder culture.

review_title: Can learn a lot from this company
pros:
Unlike Samsung Electronics, employees can have chance to fully manage the whole business process because the organization is not too big and it has simple trading business models.
If you want to learn a lot about trading business, working here will be really helpfull.
cons: This company is a lot more flexible than other Samsung affiliates, but still it's Samsung. This means there will aways be strong centralized management from Samsung Group.

pros: Office atmosphere is very friendly, pretty good bonuses is a plus, lunch compensation is fine enough. In a whole Samsung is a great place to work.
cons: Challenge is to work with korean peolpe, their culture and work attitude is quite different from ours, it is hard to work when you don't khow what are you doing and what for. In most case they don't explain it and change their decisions very often.

job_title: Systems Engineer in San Jose, CA
pros:
Team meetings are short and very productive, (no boring endless meetings)
People are friendly, no matter what nationality are they
cons: Some managers are really pain in the... Some managers goes that far that they want micromanagement on daily report. It takes sometimes over 1 hour to write the report to the manager... silly

pros: Above market rate compensation and benefits. Large human network. Great opportunity to learn new things.
cons: Heavy bureaucracy and politics. Human relationship is very hierarchical. Difficult to engage in technical debate/conversation with the seniors especially the executives. Majority of executives are pompous and arrogant for no reason as they rarely make useful decision. Many fragmented organizations doing redundant stuff. Creative R&D is not encouraged unlike the way the company portray itself. Seems fast-paced, but ironically falls behind the competitors. Nagging and control freak human resource department.

pros: If can be considered a pro you're paid  (quite low) for your work. Samsung group on your back could give you a sense of safety.
cons:
Ridiculous management all composed by korean people. If you're not korean forget to get promotions. 

Endless and countless meeting on the same subject without any decision; after 2 minutes of English the meeting language is automatically switched to korean regardless of the non Koreans participants. 

Informations are not shared, no activity plan. 
Korean culture is a heavy presence inside the company which oftenly leads to mobbing cases considering western laws and culture. 

No respect towards employees. 

Very Poor work life balance, you will be called during the weekend or holidays

pros:
I have a great desire and intention. I want to develop and develop the company. I want to invest in a serious organization where they will appreciate my work, where I can apply my skills and learn new things. I'm interested in growth in all directions.

I'm attracted to two things. This is an inevitable opportunity for career growth and good income. I also want to work in a friendly team of professionals. With people with a positive life position and moral values.

My goal is to maintain the status of the company in the market and increase its growth through sales, thereby improving our well-being.
cons: Laziness, chaos, dirt, alcohol, cigarettes, anger

job_title: User Experience Designer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Good pay and the chance to work on products that ship around the world
cons:
A shocking amount of office gossip, politics and treachery.
Tons of box checking, even for a big corporation.
Cultural and practical gaps with leadership in Korea that is never, ever going to be resolved.
No culture of teamwork or mentorship. You're on your own, all the time. Good luck.
No clear vision or communication of expectations.
High turnover of good people due to all of the above.

pros: Best of both worlds:  US offices are small, so you get a small company feel but with the power and backing of one of the largest companies in the world.   The offices have a mix of people from various product groups.  Extreme cultural diversity makes everyone feel at home.  Those with great ideas really do get ahead.   Willingness to do whatever it takes to make a project work or to please the customer.
cons: The cultural diversity can be difficult for those with low emotional intelligence.  Misunderstandings are frequent but there is a genuine desire to understand opposing views.  Definitely an environment for people who like to work hard.

review_title: Best place to stay ?! but the worst place to improve yourself.
pros:
- With relative long history, they have definitely one of the best systems in the World, in terms of process and ERP both. 
- Salary is very competitive for HQ hired, but harsh cut on locally hired
- provide many opportunities to work globally in Trading and Construction
cons:
- Highly political corporate culture without KPI for each employee. 
- No communication between associates and management
- If you are locally hired, you would not have any chance to promote to the responsible position

review_title: Great place to start your career
pros:
RATING 4.25/5
+ great people
+ amazing products to play with
+ wonderful if you are into gadgets, technology or love travelling
+ lots of career possibilities afterwards
+ free Korean language classes
+ very good supervisors and lots of support from your peers
+ nice office, and good air quality around the workplace thanks to forests and parks
+ fantastic Korean food which is incredibly cheap, too
cons:
- below average pay
- long working hours
- Chertsey is located in the middle of nowhere and trains to London take around an hour
- Korean style of management is not everyone's cup of tea
- difficult to provide product feedback to management or product development teams

review_title: Long hours, random work and sometimes rework, but technically cutting edge.
pros: They are working on some really cutting edge technologies.  The management is understanding and trying, but the work has to get done.  Generally flexible in terms of daily schedule. You can work from home some days if needed.
cons: Samsung Telecom America is the offshore for Samsung Korea and they get treated like that.  The work has to get done.  You will face some unrealistic deadline.  You may face some lack of information sharing situations.

review_title: Interning in Korea is an OK job for the right person
pros:
Brand name and recognition
Some interesting projects
People nice and respectful
People speak decent English
cons:
No future in this company as a foreigner
No chance for engineers to move back to home country subsidiary
Stuck in an outdated management system
Getting on a good team (or not) totally random
Language of the group is definitely Korean
Can be disorganized
Company does not value anyone as an individual, especially not a foreigner

pros: Very challenging and interesting problems to solve.  25% discount on Samsung products that too on dealer's price. Will get a lot to learn.
cons: Technically illiterate team leads/managers. They force you to work like donkeys. You can't provide your inputs. You are not allowed to talk to Korean managers. Most of the team leads and managers are dumb and  stubborn. They try to hide their technical ignorance from Korean managers using your talent and knowledge.  If you get good boss then it is fine. Otherwise you will fail yourself both on personal ground and professional commitment.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: The company offers pretty nice benefits. Growth is very slow and hard to advance unless you excel above and beyond.
cons:
The company while strives for globalization of workforce, it tends to heavily rely on Korean Americans in the office. The works tends to be put a lot more on Korean speaking workforce than others by far. 
The company has recently gone through so much changes including budget cut and workforce downsizing and it has started to strain those remaining and cause stress and exhaustion of working lots of overtime.

pros:
1. Company WAS involved in developing exciting projects globally
2. People are aware of who adds value and who doesn't at the company
3. Samsung name carries weight in many places, especially Korea
cons:
1. People who add value are expected to contribute more with zero additional benefit; (doing more work just results in more work assigned)
2. Extremely political and petty; (this is no joke - people complain when their e-mail address on an e-mail is listed after those of junior colleagues) 
3. Samsung Group seems to have no interest in this company other than as a holding company for the shares of Samsung Electronics that it holds

job_title: Regional Sales Manager in Kiev, Kyiv
pros: Good salary and package, innovative products.
cons:
Samsung management style is strange. If you want to develop your professional skills, make important decisions - that's all not about Samsung. You will just do what your boss said.
Everything in Company desides one person - President. Heads of departments have really low power to change something, other people spend 70% of working time to avoid attention from bosses.
Every new President do his best to destroy all, that previous President has built and make his own structure and processes.
Interesting experience,  but I don't want to repeat it - companies with corporate culture like in Samsung are in my own black list.

review_title: Trading Company Mentality Usurps Customer Confidence - Commerce, CA Office
pros: Perhaps being able to put the globally-recognized name of Samsung on a resume, even though the words and ideas of "Construction & Trading America" seem to negate that benefit.
cons: Since the Korean management team decided to "take over" an already established highly successful business, they have proceeded to alienate customers and destroy confidence with their management protocol roadblocks, communications barriers, and a lack of understanding in US-style relationship business as a model for success.

pros: Dynamic environment that has big budget projects and a huge footprint with the capabilities to do great work. Deep pockets and an abundance of resources.
cons: Difficult culture to adapt to and almost impossible to have success within as an employee outside of Korea. I've worked in multiple large corporate environments and never seen anything like this. Demanding and difficult to please.

pros: Talented people, passionate engineers. Interesting projects dealing with research and optimization.  Business trips, conferences, good benefits.
cons: Management lacking focus. Several teams working in parallel on the same project without knowing about each other - after they've finished, the best results are selected and the rest is trashed (natural selection?). Not easy to grow as an engineer or see a clear career path.

review_title: Glad for the experience but would have rather not had to go through all the BS on the way
job_title: Associate Engineering Technician in Austin, TX
pros: Benefits, 401k, some of the people you work with are good to hang out with after work
cons: Politics are ridiculous, it's all about who you know not what or how well you perform, every group is structured different even though it's all the same company.

review_title: Great Company Not so Good Work
pros: Company takes good care of its employees. Plenty of Recreational Facilities. No such pressure to stay late or anything which is great departure for 2013-14 times. This is probably due to IITians being hired.  Company is now implementing new HR Pratices albeit very slow.
cons:
The mindset of HR and Administration department is still archaic
The Salary gap between freshers and experience is huge. They are giving very high package to freshers which is sometimes much higher than the experience employees. It like the HR wants to get rid of the old employees. This is evident in the way they have implemented that long service award policies.

review_title: Good to get your career started..
pros: You get to play with the latest gadgets. The benefits and pay are competitive. You get to travel to Asia. There is a lot to learn.
cons: The management team only cares about playing the politic game to focus and drive their team. There is also a lot of tension between the HQ and employees working oversees. You will be traveling on plane for 10+ hours to South Korea few times a year depending on your job with last minute notice. Due to the time difference in Asia, there will be many days you can be working late.

review_title: Need for Agility to work in Hierarchical Organization
pros: Everything is organized, with the degree of organization at times overwhelming or in excess.  There is opportunity to do well after the initial consideration is done for HQ folks.
cons: You have to take on all the input from HQ on how and what things to get done.  There is little room the imagination or initiative, just keep your head down, listen to your supervisor and get the job done seems the general attitude.

review_title: You will manage the 50 people to sense the market portion of fridge industry
pros: Excellent co-worker with nice enviornment. Also you can learn how to analyze the market portion of appliance market in Korea and inspire you to do more study about market analyzing skill with the free course on the work portal
cons:
if you’re not scrappy then you might get in trouble.
organizing schedule is a key and most of the time. if you can arbitrate the conflict between the store and hq you’ll be ideal for this position

review_title: Exciting products but military style leadership by Korean MD
pros: Worked in the New Zealand business. Great local people at working level. Very exciting company to be part of because of all the new products that are on the cutting edge that are continually being released.
cons: Local New Zealand office Korean MD runs office like the military. Dictatorial style. Not open to opinions that do not reinforce his own and has a massive ego.

pros: Some may claim that "it may look good on the resume" OR "ok pay", but the disadvantages outweigh any faint positive. Simply put - DO NOT WORK HERE!
cons: You can expect: Bullying / Harrassment (very acceptable & normal here) Terrible work culture and inhumane treatment of employees; No work life balance (expect to work all day, all night and on weekends); incompetent management with no prior management experience or care factor when it comes to retaining or nurturing employees!

review_title: If all you want is a pay check and zero professional development...
pros: They pay well. That is the only reason as an expat to work for them in their HQ. Nothing else particularly good to say.
cons:
There is zero opportunity for professional development. 

There seems to be a general lack of trust in non-koreans and therefore an unwillingness to give them the access to the information etc they need to perform their duties. Which in turn renders them ineffective.

The management system is extremely hierarchical and top heavy, and there is a complete inability and unwillingness of any non-executive to make a decision. 

The way projects are managed is with arrogance and a huge superioty complex to non-koreans, which when coupled with the general lack of experience and knowledge in managing projects internationally is a recipe for disaster.

review_title: Very good step-on for foreign engineers to enhance their careers.
pros: It's hard for foreigners to be one of them. Most managers have English communication problems and working culture is too unique and different with global etiquetes.
cons: Thw work load is high and too high some cases for Koreans. But, the company is very poor at managing foreign engineers. It assigns good technical tasks to foreign engineers and manages so roughly, although it requires domestic engineers to fully cover all kinds of dirty jobs. So foreign engineers can enjoy their time to enhance their own skills.

pros: good health insurance benefits , big company  ..
cons: Micromanaging Every Move, if you complain to HR about management you will be out within 2 month seen several time . Not good for woman, different kind of abuse. No human touch  they want you work as a robot.

pros: Global brand awareness and latest tech devices. Good financial compensation with various non-company related benefits.
cons: Leaders from Director level and up incapable of managing team members properly. Every single direction comes from the very top. Being called an 'expert' only when needed. Opinions and recommendations aren't received at all and not taken seriously. Competitiveness of business units differ too much. HR takes care of their own KPIs only. Employees' welfare and career is non of their concern.

pros: Samsung is number one in many area's and I believe it's number one because of it's commitment to work hard and get the job done at all cost. If you want to be the best, then you have to strive to be the best and here at Samsung I believe we all strive to make that happen.
cons: Maybe being more open to working from home, the dress code, etc. This is the Valley and people want to work from home from time to time and also wear shorts, flip-flops on occasions.

review_title: Definitely one of the best Marketing Agencies

review_title: Good expat experience but not recomendable
pros:
Great opportunity to learn about real cultural differences and how to overcome them in your work place.

Korea is an amazing country to live for a period and Samsung is definitively a great name on the CV.
cons: A very Korea Company with no meritocracy and no English internal communication. Sometimes you feel like you are a nice asset to have in a meeting but just to fill in a quota

review_title: Good for a short period of time
pros: Great subsidized canteen. Free bus to campus from the nearest town. Employees get to influence the course of business from the beginning and things generally happen at a fast pace.
cons: Rather big workload which means that everyone is expected to work overtime. Top highest paying posts reserved for Koreans as they are the link to the head office. The main Samsung  office is London is in the outskirts, meaning the commute takes a long time.

pros: Strong product development ability, and treats testing element strictly. Willing to invest the new technology and marketing for the future business. Offer the  talents chances to work in the different countries and grow up with various experience.
cons: Clear upper and lower relations among the company. Opinion is not easily delivered from working level to high levels. Short term targets are pushed by the organization operating method. However, sometimes that sacrifices the long-term brand value management.

review_title: Contract work for very specific and unique project
pros: Huge learning experience, opened doors to future opportunities.  Is a global company so will have access to many different facets of the business.
cons: Work ethic in corporate culture especially with senior managment can be intense and demanding.  Very strong Korean culture can be difficult when expressing ideas to korean team, sometimes will encounter language barriers that slow efficiency.  Not enough women in senior roles.

review_title: Samsung is a world leader in Electronics
pros:
Samsung has its on set standards, its a process driven organization.
Samsung has world class manufacturing facilities across the globe, best R&D centers and people who work for 24*7 to deliver their best in all manner.
cons: Samsung is truly global company and its each subsidiary is different. If i say about SIEL (India), there is problem of office time system, it should be little flexible. Also we can not wear casual attire on any single day including Friday.

pros:
- good health coverage
- everyone in the office is friendly and fun to work with
- good work/life balance
- convenient location
- job security
cons:
- pay is mediocre at best
- very political
- it's like you're working in a different country
- upper managers do not seem to care if you're a non-korean and will converse completely in their language with no regard for politeness or etiquette of any kind
- if you're a non-korean, you practically don't exist; just a fly on the wall
- the highest position in each department is held by a rotational staff from HQ giving you no real opportunity for advancement and oh, that rotational staff has absolutely no knowledge or experience in said field... he (yes, it's always a he) floats in from HQ for approximately 5 years and then floats out, paving the way for your next floater
- trying to get anything done in this place is a joke because there's so much bureaucratic red tape and hoops to jump through: manual approval processes followed by electronic approval processes; the many, many protocols they've put in place in order to prevent embezzling (which has happened in the past) more so hinders than helps the business
- your CEO of the moment (because you get a new one every 1 or 2 years), tries too hard to be likeable that he goes around sexually and racially discriminating everyone for a cheap laugh
- this company does not care about its employees
- i've seen long time interns/temps getting passed up for full-time positions but they continue to work the full-time hours
- i've seen hardworking non-koreans getting passed up for promotions while their korean counterparts get promoted

review_title: A place to start your career, then move on.
pros: It is a fast placed company where performance is top.  You get introduced to latest technology and have access to a lot of support from HQ in Korea
cons:
1. The company requires a time commitment that is beyond a 40 hour week. This is a place where you'd succeed if you have no other interests beyond work. 
2. A lot of backstabbing so people can keep their jobs

review_title: God awful!! Worst place to work. Never meet such incompetent management.
pros: None!!!!!! Horrible place to work. Depressing and frustrating. Feel bad for some of the decent people who are still stuck there. Completely disassociated with how a business should be run. Management is so out of touch with how to do things and they're lack of knowledge for the departments they run is mind boggling! Like said no pros what so ever!
cons: Everything! Especially the management and work environment. If your not Korean management your nothing. Employees are subjected to discrimination on a regular basis and the favoritism shown to Korean employees is obvious. No knowledge of how to solve problems in an appropriate manner just pass the buck along. Management never takes responsibility for anything and when problems arise the lower level employees get blamed.

review_title: Healthcare business lacks vision, strategy and knowledge
pros: Company has a great intent of achieving and winning. With a strong leaders, there is a strong formula for success.
cons:
Very hierarchical company. Employees blindly follow directions without questioning. The healthcare business does not have the right leadership with knowledge to succeed. Consumer product mind set seems to have prevailed dragging the business. 

Rules are rigid and very in-flexible even if they do not make any sense. It is frustrating when you cannot do anything about it.

review_title: Great potential, good benefits, bad management system

- Benefits (exc salary) and facilities are top notch, modeled after the valley

pros: The reputation of Samsung Electronics employees are good. So if you decided to work in Korea, it would be a good place to start with. cons: Personal life had much less priority.  Many people were promotion-oriented, especially at the management level people. Working hours were much more than 40h, but sometimes not that tight during the working hours.

pros:

job_title: Senior Quality Engineer in Suzhou, Jiangsu

job_title: Software Developer in San Jose, CA

review_title: Lots of opportunity, tons of work, not that much salary or welfare benefits

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Warsaw, Masovia

Awful work-life balance.
Mediocre sallary.

cons: Samsung's culture is forced upon American workers through South Korean dispatchers (closed fraternity, with a military management style feel). Samsung always works hard, however, Samsung often doesn't work smart.

review_title: Good to get experience, no good to become a master

Big company - big opportunities.
Interesting corporate culture.
Variety of interesting projects, since Samsung is a leader of high-tech market.
Interesting networking.

Strong hierarchy.
Stupid unexpectable barriers from management.
No superstars, just good specialists.
Weak understanding of what software is.
Dress-code and fixed working day (no flexibility at all).

review_title: Fast paced innovative company with high expectations.
pros: Innovative company with global resources and reach. Pretty good job security and good benefits. Pay is decent but not stellar. Great daily per diem when traveling.
cons: Little recognition. Forced distribution ratings for annual reviews. Upper management gets rewarded at the expense of the foot soldiers. Perks and benefits continue to decrease as cost cutting measures take effect the past few years. Runs lean. Current employees expected to do more with less.

review_title: Sink or swim, it's up to you
pros:
- Good colleagues (many western educated Koreans)
- Amazing benefits (bonus, healthcare, pension, housing, transportation)
- Flexible work schedule (just clock 40 hours a week)

pros: A company with global reach and instantly recognizable brand anywhere. As a non-Korean employee you will be in a role that touches other parts of the world (because you would be useless in a Korea-only role) -- may have many opportunities to travel IF in the right role. Your younger Korean colleagues will be quite bright and energetic and your non-Korean colleagues will be accomplished professionals mostly from the list of companies that Samsung hires from (Blackberry, IBM, etc.). Compensation for an expat in Korea is favorable given the low expat tax rate and many of your other expenses are also covered (housing, company shuttle bus, meals on-campus).
cons: You will see a company with great potential blocked by one or more of the following: stifling hierarchy, inane rules and processes, short-termism, internal politics, personal rivalries, lack of trust, bloated middle-management, arrogance, endless reorganizations, an HQ-trumps-all mentality and/or excessive internal navel-gazing. Samsung is a company with the patience and strategic planning ability of an ADHD-afflicted 7-year-old, suffering from "instant noodle" syndrome -- any strategic direction extending past year-end simply doesn't happen due to endless reorganizations of divisions and executives. You will be thrust into ridiculous deadlines and ordered to execute. Plans change instantly on a whim of a VP -- all of a sudden the senior-level meetings you have set up with external customers all need to be canceled ... "because we're Samsung" after all. "Game of Thrones" style politics at director and above levels ... little collaboration between departments and endless efforts to dress up your work to look better than other groups. Many director-level employees are outdated dinosaurs who are simply being kept on to collect a paycheck ... Samsung functions partly as a South Korean welfare agency. Outside ideas are stifled from overseas subsidiaries and a "Not Invented Here" mentality is prevalent. Level of English at HQ is below-standard for a "global" company and you are shut out of many meetings which happen only in Korean (of course, you could learn Korean on your own time but at least the Mobile Division does not provide language classes for employees).

pros:
READ the Cons first. 

BUT… things are changing, ever so slowly. It pains me to say this, but little will change in the next few months or years, and then one fine week Samsung will wake up and panic like child that can’t find his favorite blanket and within a matter of weeks/months, Samsung will try to reorganize and evolve its culture. This strategy has worked thus far, but if it will continue to work in the future, is yet to be seen. Either way, it has meant a hemorrhaging of fantastic talent and Samsung has not lived up to its full potential. While I know that this review has been mostly negative, I will also say this; if Samsung shapes up it could easily dominate the industry. Most Samsung employees are proud that in a single year Samsung was able to turn its business around and go from feature phones to becoming the leading smart-phone manufacture. Which is pretty dumb in my opinion. If Samsung had planned and listened properly to both internal and external chatter they could possibly leading the pact instead of following Apple’s lead. This is not to say that turning the business around isn’t a great achievement, its just that Samsung probably put the same amount of man power to produce this effect in one year, that Apple took three years to craft. Thus, while Samsung may be efficient (debatable) it is not very effective.
cons:
THIS is for Samsung HQ in KOREA

So let me preface this as this is/was the structure of the company circa 2010 to mid 2011. While the company is unified under one umbrella name, it does not function as a cohesive organism. Each department is independent; this leads to a great number of rational actors and the problems that plague negotiation between departments.  To cut to the point, each HR is independent, so while one may say/state very appealing terms of contract, your actual HR may decide not to deliver /fulfill them. This is most problematic as it seems there exists no formal communication between any department - not simply from HR to HR. I mean this in the broader sense. What this means for the new employee is that he/she is often lost and cannot find the answer to his question. I digress... 

Let me first focus on HR. The problem that prevails in Samsung is that no one has a specialization. One would think that in company the size of Samsung, the HR would be headed by people that understand the department, its polices and the simple fact that HR is suppose to help make the employee's life better. But the HR as with every other division with in Samsung comes from a scattered group of people - former engineers, linguists, fresh liberal arts graduates etc... the problem with this is that these people, though they may be inherently smart (or so says their degree from the top universities of Korea), are simply not prepared for their roles. They do not know how to manage, let alone have the knowledge to support an employee. Problems are exacerbated by a number of factors; some departments reorganize themselves up to 2 times a year. I cannot say with the greatest certainty how that affects the HR, but it certainly can have a demoralizing effect on the employees.

While I am sure I can write a book about my experience thus far, allow me to narrow the scope of focus. 

Setup:
	While initial setup can be taxing and time consuming, I have never known it be as stressful or daunting as in Samsung. Most companies would have their employees working by day two, where as Samsung… you can wait upwards of two weeks. It boggles the mind to know that Samsung is a technology company yet it cannot provide its own employees with fully set-up, working computer, in the target language. The computer comes bear, and all software/drivers need to be installed – of course, the first installation is completely in Korea, making it impossible for the Korean illustrate to function. Furthermore, it is task in itself to find someone that knows how to set up the computer in English; as in the finding the correct software etc. 

Work:
	As stated before each department is independent; this translates to several departments that have overlapping responsibilities/work without any clear consensus on who should be leading/ownership or the strategy moving forward. Without making this any longer, the basic jest of it is that it entirely depends on the group one works in. But as a general rule, do not expect to be thrown in and be doing meaning full work right away. 	
	Samsung is much like the proverbial – smart, last minute college student. Eg. When Samsung could draft plans early on, the company organization/culture does not seem support such a strategic endeavor, instead things are left done at the last minute with tremendous amounts of overtime. At this point – I would say most of Samsung still functions as top-down company. Whatever the upper management decrees must be done, there is very little questioning and foresight. 

Other things to note:
-	You must work 9 hours a day; otherwise you won’t get paid – be it productive or not
-	Your work all depends on your group (I stress this point, if you have a good group then you are lucky)
-	Overtime work is almost mandatory; be it because of culture (Korean face time), organization (last minute dealings), or otherwise.
-	Language: unless you are VERY lucky, almost all communications are in Korean – emails, meetings, reports etc. 
-	Secrecy: Samsung is stupidly paranoid and groups never fully understand what other groups are doing. Often projects are repeated due to a lack of shared information. Even code that is shared, will not be fully explained.
-      Promotions are not based on actual competence, but on seniority (for the most part). Which is extremely disheartening for the ambitious. 

Samsung can be best described as from a quote that I overheard…
‘Samsung is not a global company, Samsung is a Korean company with global operations.’

One worker in one department or group will make double to triple what other similar workers make due to the name of their university, prestige of previous job, or other inscrutable factors, like how close you are to HR in your department or if you are located in Seoul vs. Suwon.

They use funny math to somehow make a $30K/year offer look like $125K on paper. They say they want to internationalize but then make everyone follow 50 year old Korean corporate structures and rules. Some people are allowed to break the rules, while others have to follow the strict rules to a T. A completely schizophrenic company that survives because of the prestige factor of working there amongst Koreans. 
The other thing, they will recruit foreigners with great fanfare, telling them how they will make great money and have a chance to expand their careers. In truth, as a foreigner, you are excluded from your work groups for not being Korean, and then given low marks for "cultural assimilation" when bonus time comes around due to low integration with the team. Your bonus comes in low, and your chances for advancement drop significantly.

review_title: Working in Samsung Electronics Mobile Division headquarter in South Korea
pros:
1. Good pay
2. Free food
3. Free transportation
cons:
1. No trust in employees. 
 - For example, there are security gates in every building and 6~7 security guards who swipe you when you pass the gate. Literally you are passing the security gate of an airport when you pass every building. And they use that stick to swipe you.
 - It is painstakingly difficult to take your computer out of the office, thus literally no one does it.

2. Poor IT infrastructure
 - Even though it is an IT company, you don't have access to almost all IT tools that allows efficient work. For example, most of the employees don't use Outlook. Recently, not even Microsoft Word.
 - Samsung has a tool called MySingle, created by Samsung SDS. And if you want to experience one of the worst IT tools in the world join the team.

3. Inefficient
 - On top of the lack of IT tools, you will see people here sit in their desks writing reports for their bosses 80% of their time. These reports are for either their boss or their boss to report to their boss. This report is revised every time it goes up the chain of command. I have spent over a day writing a 2 page presentation file for a executive here. And it was with 5 people!
 - Let me give you another fun example of inefficiency. In order to submit a form or send an email to a senior person (note, not even an executive), you need to call that person's subordenient and get her/him to understand everything about what you want to do. If you don't you willl not get your form approved or get the thing you want to get done which you wished through the email sent. FYI this might take a week to get done.

4. Endless reporting
 - Reporting will consumes 80% of your time.
 - And good reporting skill is highly valuable in Samsung Electronics. Of course reporting on the thing that you worked on and put effort into is not bad. But, in Samsung Electronics the actual work you do is not really important, it's all about reporting. And the reporting is very frequent. For instance, for some projects you will have to report to your executive, your team's executive, the CEO, etc. And for every report it will consume at least 1 day. And need to update almost every week.

5. And so much more. But you need to join to experience. Don't want to ruin ir for you.

review_title: Not an Ideal Environment for Experienced Global Talents
pros: The corporate policy is constantly being updated to reflect global standards, but change is slow and sometimes counterproductive. There is no shortage of intelligent, hard-working people with advanced degrees and professional certifications that allows for good networking opportunities. Also, the health and medical insurance/benefits are excellent for those with a family, as well as the expat package, which provides housing allowance or a furnished apartment.
cons: Ambiguous tasks and duties coupled with a rigid top-down military-based rank system cause and endless cycle of inefficiencies and endless reports. Well intentioned changes are stymied by upper management and lack of proper enforcement. Promotions are seemingly based on a fair and transparent point system, but in practice, the final decisions are made according to seniority at the company and the team's internal political clout, not on merit, skill or competence. Some senior managers have no respect for private or family emergencies and have no qualms in calling or messaging past 10:00 pm for a mundane task or question, even on the weekends. Also, some of the strict compliance policies have become roadblocks to carrying out simple tasks that seriously hinders efficiency. Therefore, expats with a particular skill set or professional background (especially at a non-executive level) would do well to heed all the advice in these reviews as they are accurate reflections of the work life, culture and environment at this company. In my opinion, this company is ideal for anyone who would like a stable job for life and is used to the top-down, seniority based culture which demands absolute dedication and loyalty that is prevalent in Asia. On the surface, things may seem copacetic but there is deep resentment and distrust between local and non-local staff due to cultural differences and misplaced personnel who have no clue as to what they are expected to do.
